abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Ulaanbaatar
            Services Improvement Project for Mongolia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the project
            was intended to provide improved water supply service to the
            urban poor. It is now clear that the government should have
            provided subsidies for this kind of project. However, the
            true nature of the project was not fully documented in the
            project appraisal document, or PAD, and hence the municipal
            government did not take any action to provide such
            operational subsidies. This issue should have been dealt
            with at appraisal, and the role of the government should
            have been more clearly defined upfront. Prior to project
            implementation, it is important to have clear guidelines on
            cost sharing and responsibilities of households. Where
            feasible, customers should contribute financially to
            investments to foster their ownership. It is important that
            the project owner educate users more proactively to inform
            them of their responsibilities to maintaining the system.
            One of the major design flaws of the pilot private
            connections in Dambadarjaa was the estimation of water
            consumption. The standards in the urban area are not
            applicable for the current situation of ger areas. It is
            important to establish and apply standards that are suitable
            for ger areas.
